rationale: This ban may get reversed, but having Labjace in the command zone seems too powerful. This ban (like Narset and Ashiok) was made in the same rules change that legalized planeswalkers, so none of them have been tested in practice.

Crippling and asymmetrical stax piece in ideal colors in the uncommon slot would homogeneize commander choices, and would appear so often that it would essentially remove toolbox decks as an archetype.

Like Ashiok, crippling, cheap, and completely non-committal. Would homogeneize deckbuilding, and would be a boring "obligatory" Uncommon slot in many decks. You'd need to account for your opponents' Narsets whenever making a deck, which is a hallmark sign of a card that would be bad for meta diversity.
This ban is a hand-me-down from EDH that has not yet been evaluated. The majority opinion so far is to keep it banned.
This ban is a hand-me-down from EDH that has not yet been evaluated. (As Spouse)

Considering that Erayo can be your third spell, and it counts opponents' spells, and that it counters EACH opponent's spells, and that it becomes less removeable once flipped, this EDH ban is likely to stick.
This card is incredibly good, but hasn't been evaluated for play in SDH
This ban is a hand-me-down from EDH that has not yet been evaluated.
This hand-me-down ban from EDH is probably going to stick because it makes reanimator strategies much less interesting: It's always either Griselbrand or Thassa's Oracle.

Drannith punishes commander-centric gameplans, which are exactly what this format seeks to enable and encourage. Drannith's effect would be okay if it specified "noncommander", but for the simplicity of the format, it's been

This EDH ban, like Griselbrand, will almost certainly stick. A very important subtlety of this card is that you can activate its ability at instant speed, so if it doesn't get countered, you can always get your cards from it, and unlike Ad Nauseam, it imposes no deckbuilding restrictions.

Prophet's abilities are greater than the sum of their parts: Unlike Seedborn Muse, you aren't limited to instant-speed spells and abilities, and unlike Vedalken Orrery, you have mana to cast those Flash-speed spells. This is made significantly worse when you remember that everything having Flash speed means that you can sandbag many win-cons like people did with Flash.
Hand-me-down ban from EDH. Very likely to be unbanned in the library.
Hand-me-down ban from EDH. Has not yet been evaluated.

Considering that Erayo can be your third spell, and it counts opponents' spells, and that it counters EACH opponent's spells, and that it becomes less removeable once flipped, this EDH ban is likely to stick.
Hand-me-down ban from EDH. Has not yet been re-evaluated.
Hand-me-down ban from EDH, but has a good chance of sticking.
Ideally there would be a more nuanced reason that just "it's too good", but that's the consensus at the moment.

This card is contentious because of the SDH social contract. See, if people follow what's written there, then they'll never make a deal to allow the caster to draw cards: If possible, they'll simply deck whoever casts it. But that begs the question: Is dealmaking formally part of 'playing to win'? At the moment, the consensus seems to be yes, so this card is staying banned.
This card is as a candidate for to stay banned because you can blow out your hand or sacrifice your lands for some benefit, then wipe your opponents out without actually winning.
Black Lotus is staying banned primarily because it's the best fast mana in the game, and it's one of the few fast mana sources that players are okay with not playing.
The Moxen are banned over cards like Mana Crypt and Jeweled Lotus because they give an (extra) advantage to players using more colors.
The Moxen are banned over cards like Mana Crypt and Jeweled Lotus because they give an (extra) advantage to players using more colors.

Its combo with Protean Hulk is simply too dominant. The fact that it's not only 2-mana (with easy) pips and *instant-speed* puts it on a level above Thoracle/Consult. It also encourages a play pattern of everyone sandbagging because the last player to "go for it" wins.
It's rare that you can reasonably call a card "too oppressive", but Karakas is just that.

If Flash is the card that ruined cEDH (for a time), then Time Vault is the card that ruined No Banlist cEDH. Especially given that it's colorless, it's an extremely dominant strategy that would eat up 4 or 5 slots in every deck and cause a lot of stale wins.
This card is essentially a silver-border card, and like many such cards, does not work online, and rewards a skill that is not part of the core Magic experience.
Everything said in the rationale for Falling Star applies here: Doesn't work online, and your ability (or lack of ability) to flip a card accurately should not matter in a game of Magic.
Simply too powerful.

Thassa's Oracle had very efficient two-card-combos with Demonic Consultation and Tainted Pact that were completely commander-agnostic, gameplan-agnostic, and non-committal. This was exacerbated by the fact that Thoracle was in the two best colors, and had the effect of devaluing commander participation in combos. Additionally, Laboratory Maniac still exists, so more creative/commander-centric uses of Thassa's Oracle can largely continue to exist.

Underworld Breach, like Thassa's Oracle, gave many decks a "free" win condition for being in certain color identities, and made it possible to run pure "goodstuff" decks whose commanders were just value engines with no combo participation. This was the meta, and resulted in overall less diverse and commander-centric gameplay, despite Breach itself being a very interesting and stax-vulnerable card. Unlike Thoracle, there's a chance that Breach comes back off the ban list at some point.
Was too homogenizing in cEDH. Was never used in SDH, as the format was dormant at the time of its release.
